Actually, the Bible tells believers to be discerning. When they are told to not judge, it means that Jesus, alone, will determine where we all spend eternity--that is not our decision.

The Bible also makes it clear that we all are sinners and we should repent and change our behaviors. Changing behaviors is often very difficult, but, we all should try very hard. Using your logic, we should decriminalize pedophilia and child abuse--we should not exclude pedophiles and child abusers from decent society. The Catholic Church has stated tenets. A Pope is not THE Catholic Church. Whether we embrace the Catholic Church of Christianity, this is what the the Catholic Church believes. Certainly the Catholic Church does not believe in abusing people, but, some people who don't embrace the tenets are not invited to join. Just like if the Dems take the Senate next election cycle, I doubt that they would ask Ted Cruz to lead the Senate. Like no whites allowed in the Congressional Black Caucus. It's just the way it is.

The Church does not distinguish between "good" and 'bad" sinners in terms of who can receive communion. The Church says that all must examine their consciences, confess their sins, and intend to "go and sin no more" before receiving communion. Those that cannot or will not do so are not to recieve communion. It is not a punishment -- it is an incentive.

Let's say a man dumps his wife of 20 years with whom he has three kids for his hot new girlfriend. He obtains a divorce from the wife and a civil marriage to the girfriend. The Church says that he cannot receive communion, which is a sign of repentence and reconciliation, while he continues to live with the girlfriend/new "wife."

Some other man who committed adultery while still married but did not leave his wife is similarly required to go to confession and break off the adulterous relationship before receiving communion. The two situations are treated the same. The difference is that the former situation is known to everyone while the latter is known only to the individuals involved.

What's easy to lose track of in these debates, and what some seem to be deliberately confusing, is the distance between offering wider forgiveness and acceptance, and acquiescing to the demands of modernity.

The Church is not considering encouraging divorce or abortion. It is looking for ways to minister to parishioners affected by these life events. It is a fundamental belief of the Church, sometimes mocked by outsiders, that everyone is a sinner, and that we therefore should not judge one another. It is hard to reconcile this belief with a system of exclusion (from Communion and from community) that applies only selectively to some of the sinful.

Such systems of exclusion belie the Church's stated beliefs, rather than enforcing them. Whether it was the intention of these systems or not, they create a dichotomy in the church between "good sinners" and "bad sinners," which is incoherent and meaningless in a Church that teaches that only God is good.
